summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The Government is submitting proposed redactions to 'Exhibit C' of the defendant's pre-trial motions to protect victim and third-party privacy, and notes the defense has no objection.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this government letter is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) referenced in the letter. The document concerns redactions to an exhibit filed in support of her pre-trial motions.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who is respectfully submitting this letter to the court.

connections.description: Strauss, as U.S. Attorney, is part of the prosecution team bringing the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Court Order on Proposed Redactions
events.description: The Court issued an order directing the Government to confer with defense counsel and submit proposed redactions to Exhibit C of the defendant's pre-trial motion memorandum.

events.title: Government Submits Redaction Proposal
events.description: The Government submits this letter and its proposed redactions for Exhibit C to the Court, noting the defense has no objection.

locations: United States Courthouse (Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: The document is a procedural filing concerning the protection of victim and third-party privacy in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case.
The Government is proposing redactions to 'Exhibit C' attached to Maxwell's pre-trial motions, citing the privacy interests of victims and third parties.
The defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell has indicated it has no objection to the Government's proposed redactions.
The proposed redactions are based on legal standards from the Second Circuit case Lugosch v. Pyramid Co. of Onondaga.
